question: How does Semantic Unifier project varied Semantic Features into the unified node feature space?
relevant_context: To address semantic isolation across domains, we employ a semantic unifier module that preprocesses node features without requiring additional training.

Given the feature matrix X, we utilize singular value decomposition (SVD) in extracting important latent features as follows:

    \[ \widetilde{X} = \mathrm{LayerNorm}(U_k^\top X) \]

where LayerNorm represents layer normalization, ensuring numerical stability. If k is smaller than d, SVD will use a reduced rank to decompose X, with the remaining dimensions zero-padded to reach d. This ensures that the unified features \(\widetilde{X}\) maintain a consistent dimensionality d across different graph data. Besides, the relative spatial distances between nodes are preserved in the unified features due to the nature of SVD.
final_answer: The Semantic Unifier applies singular value decomposition (SVD) to the original node feature matrix X to extract its top-k latent components (i.e. the leading singular vectors), projects X onto these components, applies layer normalization for numerical stability, and then zero-pads (or truncates) to a fixed dimension d. This yields a unified node feature matrix of consistent size that preserves the relative distances among nodes.

In this way it projects all of your varied input features into one consistent d-dimensional node feature space.

question: How does SCMP extend CMP's conditional message passing to incorporate semantic augmentations?
relevant_context: To effectively leverage semantic features in the CMP process while avoiding these challenges, we propose a novel message passing framework called Semantic Conditional Message Passing (SCMP), including two core techniques: Semantic-injected Entity Initialization and Global-local Semantic Encoding.

Instead of using the original semantic features, we inject the semantic neighbor labels into the entity initialization. The improved initialization function is defined as follows: h^{0}_{i|q} = I(i=q)¬∑e_q + I(i‚ààN^{sem}_{x,q})¬∑v_{sem}, where v_{sem} is a trainable vector shared across all semantic neighbors and N^{sem}_{x,q} comes from the unified feature matrix.
In this schema, the initial representations of these neighbor entities are not all-zero vectors, enabling them to propagate high-order semantic messages from the very first layer of CMP.

To address the remaining isolation of raw semantic features, SCMP employs two parallel CMP channels: a local channel that performs the standard query-conditional message passing, and a global channel that initializes relations with all-ones vectors and entities with their unified semantic features. The outputs of these two channels are then merged by a small MLP to produce the final conditional triple representations.
final_answer: SCMP extends the standard CMP framework by (1) altering the node initialization step so that entities identified as semantic neighbors (via a precomputed, SVD-based unified feature space) receive a shared trainable ‚Äòsemantic neighbor‚Äô embedding instead of zeros, and (2) running CMP in two parallel channels‚Äîa query-conditional (local) channel and a query-agnostic (global) channel seeded by the unified semantic features‚Äîand then merging their outputs via an MLP. Together, these augmentations allow SCMP to inject high-order semantic information into every layer of conditional message passing while preserving CMP‚Äôs theoretical expressiveness.

question: How does CBAM draw on existing channel-attention and spatial-attention mechanisms for feature refinement?
relevant_context: Fig. 2 illustrates the overview of the CBAM. It comprises two successive sub-modules: channel-attention and spatial-attention [37]. The CBAM adapts to enhance the intermediate feature map at each convolutional block of deep networks.

The CBAM consecutively evaluates 1D channel attention map M_ch and a 2D spatial attention map M_sp for a given intermediate feature map F as input. The complete attention process can be described as: F' = M_ch(F) ‚äô F, F'' = M_sp(F') ‚äô F'.

Each channel in a feature map serves as a feature detector, with channel attention focusing on 'what' is significant to an input image. As shown in Fig 3, the spatial size of the input feature is squeezed to optimize the channel attention. Therefore, CAM uses average-pooled and max-pooled features simultaneously.

CAM focuses on 'what' is significant to an input image, whereas SAM focuses on 'where' an informative part of an image is located. The evaluation of spatial attention covers applying average-pooling and max-pooling along the channel axis and concatenating them to extract representative features. After concatenation, a convolutional layer is applied to generate SAM, M_sp.
final_answer: CBAM refines features by chaining two attention mechanisms: first a channel-attention module (CAM) that pools spatial information (average and max), passes it through a shared MLP to produce a 1D channel-attention map and multiplies it with the feature map (focusing on ‚Äòwhat‚Äô is important), then a spatial-attention module (SAM) that pools channel information (average and max), concatenates the results, applies a 7√ó7 convolution to produce a 2D spatial-attention map and multiplies it with the intermediate feature (focusing on ‚Äòwhere‚Äô the important regions are).

The red‚Äêboxed module is nothing more exotic than a ‚ÄúConvolutional Block Attention Module‚Äù (CBAM) as introduced in Woo et al. (2018)‚Äîin other words, the network literally just ‚Äúplugs in‚Äù two off-the-shelf attention blocks to every convolutional layer:

 1.  **Channel Atten¬≠tion (CAM)**  
    ‚Äì Squeeze: apply both global average‚Äêpooling and global max‚Äêpooling over H√óW, turning each C√óH√óW feature‚Äêmap tensor into two C√ó1√ó1 context vectors.  
    ‚Äì Excitation: feed those two vectors through a shared two‚Äêlayer MLP (with a small hidden bottleneck) to produce a C√ó1√ó1 ‚Äúwhat-to-look-at‚Äù weight vector.  
    ‚Äì Reweight: multiply that 1D vector back into the original C channels (Hadamard product), boosting ‚Äúimportant‚Äù channels, suppressing noisy ones.

 2.  **Spatial Atten¬≠tion (SAM)**  
    ‚Äì Squeeze: apply max‚Äê and average‚Äêpooling across channels to get two 1√óH√óW maps.  
    ‚Äì Combine & Convolve: concatenate them into a 2√óH√óW tensor, run a single 7√ó7 convolution to produce a 1√óH√óW spatial mask.  
    ‚Äì Reweight: multiply that 2D mask back into the C√óH√óW volume, sharpening ‚Äúwhere‚Äù in each feature‚Äêmap the network should focus.

By simply cascading CAM then SAM at each convolutional block, the CBAM ‚Äúdraws on‚Äù (i.e. re-uses) these two proven attention recipes to refine the feature maps both in the channel dimension (‚Äúwhat‚Äù to amplify) and the spatial dimension (‚Äúwhere‚Äù to look), before handing them off to the next layer.

question: How does CartoonX extend pixel RDE into the wavelet domain for smoother explanations?
relevant_context: CartoonX is a novel explanation technique that is a special case of RDE. CartoonX first executes RDE in the discrete wavelet position-scale domain of an image X and then visualizes the wavelet mask M as a pixel-wise smooth picture. Wavelets efficiently represent 2D piece-wise smooth pictures, commonly known as cartoon-like images, along with providing optimum representations for piece-wise smooth 1D functions [45]. Algorithm 1 illustrates the steps for obtaining CartoonX explanations.
final_answer: CartoonX extends pixel RDE by carrying out the rate‚Äêdistortion explanation not on raw pixels but on the image‚Äôs discrete wavelet coefficients. It first transforms the image into its wavelet position‚Äìscale domain, applies RDE to derive a sparse mask over those wavelet components, and then reconstructs that mask back into pixel space to produce a smooth, cartoon-like explanation.
masked_question: How does [mask1] extend pixel RDE into the wavelet domain for smoother explanations?
caption: Figure 1: The proposed explainable Cervix-AID-Net model for high-risk and low-risk classification.
response:
Step 1 ‚Äì Identify what‚Äôs in the red box (mask1):  
If you look at the bottom panel of the figure under ‚ÄúExplainable Artificial Intelligence,‚Äù the second module from the left (outlined in red) is labeled ‚ÄúCartoonX Explanations.‚Äù  

Step 2 ‚Äì Recall what pixel‚ÄêRDE does:  
‚Ä¢ Pixel‚ÄêRDE solves a constrained optimization over a sparse pixel‚Äêmask so as to leave only those pixels that are most important to the network‚Äôs decision.  
‚Ä¢ In practice it relaxes the binary‚Äêmask problem into a continuous one, but the end result is still a map of individual pixels.  
‚Ä¢ This pixel‚Äêwise mask can be very noisy and jagged, because nothing enforces any spatial smoothness among neighboring pixels.  

Step 3 ‚Äì What CartoonX adds (and how it ‚Äúextends‚Äù pixel‚ÄêRDE):  
‚Ä¢ CartoonX is in fact a special case of RDE, but carried out not in the raw‚Äêpixel basis, but in a discrete wavelet basis (i.e. position‚Äìscale domain).  
‚Ä¢ It first takes the image, applies a wavelet transform to yield a set of coefficients at various positions and scales.  
‚Ä¢ It then performs the same sparse‚Äêmask optimization (the RDE procedure) over those wavelet coefficients rather than pixels.  
‚Ä¢ Finally it inverts the masked wavelet coefficients back to the pixel domain, yielding a ‚Äúcartoon‚Äêlike‚Äù (piecewise‚Äêsmooth) saliency map.  

Step 4 ‚Äì Why this gives smoother explanations:  
‚Ä¢ Wavelets are known to represent piecewise‚Äêsmooth structures very efficiently. Masking coefficients in wavelet space and then reconstructing forces the explanation to consist of large, smooth ‚Äúblobs‚Äù rather than isolated noisy pixels.  

Answer:  
CartoonX extends pixel‚ÄêRDE by moving the sparse‚Äêmask optimization into a discrete wavelet (position‚Äìscale) domain. It masks out unimportant wavelet coefficients instead of raw pixels, and then inverts the wavelet transform to produce a smoothly varying, ‚Äúcartoon-style‚Äù saliency map.

Step-by-step reasoning:

1.   Mask1 = the CBAM attention module inserted after each convolutional block.  
2.   The channel-attention part of CBAM learns ‚Äúwhat‚Äù feature‚Äêmaps (i.e. which channels) are most informative for discriminating low- versus high-risk cervical tissue.  
3.   The spatial-attention part of CBAM learns ‚Äúwhere‚Äù in each feature‚Äêmap the crucial cues (e.g. lesion boundaries, acetowhitening, vascular patterns) lie.  
4.   By placing one CBAM after every convolutional layer, the network is repeatedly forced to re-weigh its feature channels and spatial locations at each depth.  
5.   This continual re-calibration suppresses irrelevant patterns (e.g. specular highlights, background cervical anatomy) and amplifies subtle pathological cues.  
6.   As a result, the learned feature hierarchy becomes more focused and discriminative, boosting the model‚Äôs ability to pick out the small color and texture changes that signal high-grade lesions.

Answer: By interleaving CBAM blocks between each convolutional layer, the network constantly refines both ‚Äúwhat‚Äù it looks at (the most informative channels) and ‚Äúwhere‚Äù it looks (the most salient spatial locations).  That repeated channel- and spatial-attention sharpening greatly enhances its capacity to capture the fine, discriminative cervical features needed for reliable high-risk versus low-risk classification.

question: How does CartoonX methodology improve explanation smoothness compared to pixel RDE in model interpretation?
relevant_context: CartoonX is a novel explanation technique that is a special case of RDE. CartoonX first executes RDE in the discrete wavelet position-scale domain of an image X and then visualizes the wavelet mask M as a pixel-wise smooth picture. Wavelets efficiently represent 2D piece-wise smooth pictures, commonly known as cartoon-like images, along with providing optimum representations for piece-wise smooth 1D functions [45].

Our analysis shows that explanations given by CartoonX lie around the cervix region, which is the most crucial part of the image. The reason for a more meticulous explanation of CartoonX is its ability to extract relevant piece-wise smooth parts of an image instead of relevant pixel sparse regions. The sparsity in the wavelet domain captures interpretable input features from the image compared to sparsity in the pixel domain, instance-based explanations, and output neuron activations. Our analysis shows that CartoonX captures piece-wise smooth explanations that can reveal relevant piece-wise smooth patterns that are not easily visible with existing grad-CAM that operates on the output feature maps and pixel-based methods like LIME and pixel RDE.
final_answer: CartoonX improves explanation smoothness by performing RDE in the wavelet domain and then rendering the resulting mask as a pixel-wise smooth image. By exploiting wavelets‚Äô ability to represent piece-wise smooth structures, CartoonX yields contiguous, smooth explanation regions, in contrast to the highly sparse, non-stationary pixel-level masks produced by pixel RDE.

1. In the figure you pointed out, the blue-boxed module is labeled ‚Äúpixel RDE Explanations,‚Äù and the red-boxed one is ‚ÄúCartoonX Explanations.‚Äù  

2. From the text (section 3.4.3‚Äì3.4.4), pixel RDE works by learning a sparse mask directly in pixel space.  Because it enforces sparsity one pixel at a time, its resulting saliency maps tend to be ‚Äúnon-stationary‚Äù and noisy‚Äîbright speckles here and there rather than a clean, connected highlight.  

3. CartoonX, in contrast, is a special case of RDE that solves the same masking problem in the discrete wavelet (position-scale) domain.  By enforcing sparsity on wavelet coefficients, CartoonX naturally picks out piece-wise smooth image components.  When you invert back to pixel space, you get a smooth, contiguous explanation map rather than a jittery one.  

4. In short, CartoonX‚Äôs use of the wavelet basis enforces smoothness at reconstruction time, whereas pixel RDE‚Äôs pixel-level sparsity does not, so CartoonX explanations look far smoother and more visually coherent.  

Answer:  
CartoonX improves smoothness by performing its sparse‚Äêmask optimization in the wavelet domain (targeting piece-wise smooth wavelet coefficients) and then reconstructing back to the image.  This yields contiguous, smooth saliency regions.  Pixel RDE, by contrast, applies sparsity directly in pixel space, producing scattered, noisy masks.

question: How does incorporating DepRoBERTa, Llama3-8B, and Qwen2-72B-Instruct ensure high-confidence pseudo-labels?
relevant_context: We use a combination of Qwen2-72B-Instruct, along with fine-tuned DepRoBERTa and Llama3-8B models on the  labeled posts to generate pseudo-labels for unlabeled data, as depicted in Fig. 1 (a), rightmost.
Specifically, we only kept posts for which all three models predicted the same labels, and discarded the rest in case of disagreement.
By doing so, we retain only high-confidence pseudo-labels, which allow us to reduce model-specific biases, resulting in a cleaner dataset for fine-tuning later on.
final_answer: By requiring that DepRoBERTa, Llama3-8B, and Qwen2-72B-Instruct all agree on the same label for each unlabeled post and discarding any posts where they disagree. This consensus‚Äêbased filtering yields only high‚Äêconfidence pseudo‚Äêlabels and reduces model‚Äêspecific noise.

     ‚Ä¢  [mask2] = Llama3-8B (a decoder‚Äêonly language model fine-tuned to do the same task)

     ‚Äì  End up with a much cleaner, higher‚Äêconfidence pseudo‚Äêlabeled set (‚âà900 posts)  

That high‚Äêprecision ‚Äúthree‚Äêway agreement‚Äù is exactly what gives you confidence in your pseudo‚Äêlabels before you fold them back into your larger training pool.

From n labeled data, we assign the ensemble weight w_i to the models, with a weight of 2 for Qwen2-72B-Instruct, and a weight of 1 for the other four models. This means that the prediction of Qwen2-72B-Instruct counts twice, whereas all other models count once.
final_answer: In the weighted majority vote, Qwen2-72B-Instruct is given a weight of 2 while each Llama3-8B (and the other models) is given a weight of 1, so Qwen‚Äôs vote effectively counts twice as much as any single Llama3-8B vote.

Step 2 ‚Äì Why relying solely on Qwen2-72B-Instruct for pseudo-labels is ethically fraught  
1. Model bias and unvetted judgments  
   ‚Ä¢ Qwen2-72B-Instruct inherits biases from its pretraining data (news, web forums, etc.).  
   ‚Ä¢ Left unchecked, it may systematically over- or under-label certain demographic or linguistic groups (e.g., non-native English speakers, youths, etc.).  
2. Risk of false positives and false negatives  
   ‚Ä¢ A false negative (failing to flag someone truly at risk) could mean missing an opportunity for intervention.  
   ‚Ä¢ A false positive (mistakenly flagging a benign post) could lead to unnecessary alarm or stigmatization.  
3. Lack of clinical oversight  
   ‚Ä¢ Suicide risk assessment is a sensitive, high-stakes medical decision. Relying only on an LLM without human-expert review violates best practices for mental-health screening.  
4. Accountability and transparency  
   ‚Ä¢ If Qwen2-72B-Instruct makes an erroneous pseudo-label, there is no clear chain of custody or interpretability mechanism to trace or correct that error.  
5. Privacy and consent concerns  
   ‚Ä¢ Feeding user posts into a large, externally hosted LLM may contravene privacy regulations or user expectations about how their data will be used.

In sum, using Qwen2-72B-Instruct alone risks amplifying model biases, producing harmful misclassifications in a life-critical application, and sidestepping both clinical oversight and user privacy safeguards.

question: How could alternative loss functions impact the fine-tuning efficacy of Llama3-8B and Gemma2-9B?
relevant_context: Since F1 Score is computed via precision and recall, it is not differentiable. To directly optimize the F1 score, we use Macro Double Soft F1, introduced by [33], as our loss function.
We found that optimizing with this loss function in our experiment data gains some performance boost compared with other common choices such as Cross Entropy (Table VI).
final_answer: Using an alternative loss function like standard cross‚Äêentropy instead of Macro Double Soft F1 would likely reduce fine-tuning efficacy for Llama3-8B and Gemma2-9B, since the paper reports that Macro Double Soft F1 yields a measurable performance boost over more common losses such as cross-entropy.

Both of these decoder-only LLMs are fine-tuned on the same four-class suicide‚Äêrisk task using the Macro Double Soft F1 loss.  Now: what would happen if we swapped in a different loss?

1.  Cross-Entropy (CE) Loss

    ‚Äì In practice you‚Äôd probably see higher overall accuracy but lower Macro-F1 than with Soft F1.

    ‚Äì Llama3-8B, which is relatively robust to gradient noise, might benefit noticeably‚Äîimproved recall on ‚ÄúAttempt,‚Äù for example‚Äîwhile Gemma2-9B might still lag on the hardest classes unless weights are very carefully tuned.

    ‚Äì Focal adds a term that down-weights ‚Äúeasy‚Äù examples and focuses training on hard, ambiguous ones.  
    ‚Äì You would likely see both Llama3-8B and Gemma2-9B improve precision on the borderline posts (e.g. those between Ideation and Behavior), at the cost of a bit more training instability and slower convergence.

question: What limitations might arise from separate spatial and temporal codebooks in handling complex facial motion?
relevant_context: Figure 13 illustrates a failure case in which our method may introduce video blurring.
This occurs when the character‚Äôs motion is excessively dynamic or when camera switching leads to discontinuities in facial features between frames.
final_answer: Using separate spatial and temporal codebooks can fail to capture very dynamic facial motions or abrupt frame-to-frame changes, leading to video blurring and discontinuities in the restored facial features.

5. In practice this leads to coarse quantization of fast motion, temporal misalignment of features (ghosting or flicker), and overall blurring in regions where strong cross-frame spatial cues and motion cues must be modeled together.

Because spatial and temporal information are quantized in two independent codebooks ([mask1] vs. [mask2]), the model cannot learn rich joint spatio-temporal patterns. Highly dynamic or non-rigid facial motions (rapid expressions, occlusions, camera changes) will fall between codewords in one or the other book, leading to quantization artifacts, blurring, ghosting or flicker when motion is complex.

question: What motivates combining temporal attention and motion residual before quantization in STLookUp?
relevant_context: Compared to image face enhancement, the difficulty of video face enhancement lies in maintaining the consistency of facial features and background details between frames.
The discretization nature of a codebook dictates that applying it directly to video tasks often results in poor temporal consistency, leading to the common flickering problem.
In addition, conventional codebooks are limited to capturing spatial features and fail to account for the motion information embedded in the videos.

To tackle the above challenges, we propose learnable motion-aware spatial-temporal codebooks, where the spatial codebook C_S records portrait features and the temporal codebook C_T stores motion residuals between frames.
The spatial latents z_h,S are directly derived from z_h, whereas the temporal latents z_h,T incorporate inter-frame temporal-attention (TA) information and motion residuals, defined as follows:
final_answer: They combine temporal attention and motion residual so that the temporal codebook can capture both inter-frame correlations and explicit motion dynamics, thereby improving temporal consistency and reducing flickering when quantizing video latents.

In STLookUp we don‚Äôt feed the codebook a ‚Äúraw‚Äù attention map or a ‚Äúraw‚Äù frame difference on its own, but we first fuse them.  The reason is that TA gives you broad, context-aware cues about which regions in frame t‚Äâ‚àí‚Äâk should talk to which regions in frame t, while the motion residual supplies the precise pixel-level shift.  By adding the two together before you quantize, your temporal codebook learns atoms that carry both global attention-style correlations and fine‚Äìgrained motion offsets.  That richer, motion-aware latent is what lets STLookUp snap to the right code entries and thereby eliminate flicker while still preserving detailed dynamics.

question: Why leverage a pre-trained DINOv2 feature network with multi-scale discriminator heads for adversarial training?
relevant_context: Due to the instability and artifact-prone nature of training video-level VQGANs, we propose to leverage a partially initialized and more powerful discriminator.
Specifically, the discriminator consists of a frozen pre-trained feature network, such as DINOv2 [33, 36, 37], paired with a set of trainable lightweight discriminator heads.
final_answer: Because training video-level VQGANs tends to be unstable and prone to artifacts, using a frozen pre-trained DINOv2 feature network together with multi-scale discriminator heads provides a stronger, more stable discriminator that helps suppress artifacts and stabilize adversarial training.

This lets you judge realism simultaneously at coarse (global layout, face shape) and fine (skin texture, micro-expressions, motion cues) scales.  
4.  During adversarial training, the generator gets gradients from all of these heads.  The frozen pre-trained backbone ensures those gradients remain well-behaved and semantically grounded, while the multi-scale heads drive the generator to refine details and enforce consistency at every level.  
   
In short, freezing a strong, pre-trained network like DINOv2 gives you stable, meaningful feature spaces right out of the box, and adding multiple discriminator heads ensures your adversarial loss ‚Äúsees‚Äù both global structure and fine detail‚Äîtogether yielding much more stable training and far fewer flickers or artifacts.

2. How subword methods work at a high level  
   ‚Ä¢ You start with characters (or bytes), then merge the most frequent pairs into ‚Äúsubwords,‚Äù iterating until you have a fixed-size vocabulary of common subwords.  
   ‚Ä¢ New words are then decomposed into those subwords, guaranteeing you never see a completely unknown chunk but only familiar pieces.

   a. It first extracts every distinct cell string from the table and ‚Äútokenizes‚Äù it with the LLM‚Äôs own vocabulary.  
   b. It then sorts those cells by how many tokens they would normally require‚Äîshortest first‚Äîso that the easiest mappings get claimed before the trickier, longer ones (this helps avoid collisions).  
   c. For each cell, instead of accepting however many LLM‚Äêtokens it originally needed, it tries to ‚Äúpack‚Äù that entire cell into at most two tokens.  
      ‚Äì If it‚Äôs already one token, leave it alone (single‚Äêtoken preservation).  
      ‚Äì If it‚Äôs more, look for the best two‚Äêtoken split that (a) still uniquely identifies that string in the table and (b) ideally reuses whole subwords from the base tokenizer rather than chopping into new ones.  
   d. It also has special bracket-aware logic so it doesn‚Äôt accidentally split inside ‚Äú{‚Ä¶}‚Äù or ‚Äú[‚Ä¶]‚Äù and create invalid JSON.

4. Why this is just a dynamic, one‚Äêoff subword vocabulary

   ‚Ä¢ Downstream, the LLM sees only these short, familiar tokens (no repeated unknown sub‚Äêsplits), so it burns far fewer context slots on domain-specific jargon.

5. The payoff  
   ‚Ä¢ You end up reducing the overall token count‚Äîoften by 30‚Äì40% or more‚Äîwithout sacrificing the exact string content (because the decoder simply looks up each surrogate token and restores the original text).

question: How does Syntax Corrector‚Äôs LLM‚ÄìCode Executor interaction reflect iterative refinement methodologies?

To address these challenges, we developed a Syntax Corrector, based on reflective agentic framework.

Specifically, the Syntax Corrector accepts a syntactically invalid JSON as input and produces a syntactically valid JSON through iterative refinement. This cycle of ‚Äúgenerate ‚Üí execute ‚Üí reflect ‚Üí regenerate‚Äù is repeated‚Äîi.e., iteratively refined‚Äîuntil the JSON is syntactically valid or a preset iteration limit is reached.

Each cycle uses the executor‚Äôs concrete error output to guide the LLM‚Äôs next edit, steadily improving the JSON‚Äôs syntax until it is guaranteed valid.

question: How does Token-based Encoding reduce token count while preserving semantic uniqueness across table cells?
relevant_context: Next, we apply our custom token-based encoding technique. The goal here is to represent the content of each cell with the minimum number of tokens while ensuring that each cell has a unique representation.

Prior to encoding, we first sort the cells in ascending order based on the number of tokens they contain. This strategy allows us to resolve potential collisions more easily, as cells with fewer tokens are processed first. A collision occurs when two distinct cell contents map to overlapping token sequences.

Our encoding process incorporates several high-level heuristics to enhance efficiency and accuracy:
 a. Single Token Preservation: If a cell‚Äôs content consists of a single token, it remains unchanged.
 b. Multi-Token Optimization: For cells with multiple tokens, we aim to represent the content using only two tokens whenever possible.
 c. Bracket Handling: We handle incomplete bracket sequences by checking if a token starts with an opening bracket (e.g., [, {) and lacks a matching closing bracket. In such cases, we concatenate subsequent tokens until the bracket is closed.

The overall objective is to use the fewest tokens possible while maintaining uniqueness across all cell contents. By treating each tokenized cell as a unit, we can reduce the total number of tokens significantly without losing semantic integrity.
final_answer: Token-based Encoding reduces token count by first sorting cells by their initial token length to avoid collisions, then applying heuristics that preserve single-token cells unchanged, represent multi-token cells in only two tokens where possible, and handle bracketed sequences in a way that prevents syntax errors. This approach ensures each cell is encoded into a minimal yet unique token sequence, thereby reducing overall tokens while retaining semantic distinctions between cells.

A side‚Äêtable of these mappings is kept so that, after the LLM finishes, we can decode the short tokens back into the original cell text.

question: Why integrate a non-linear projection head before computing margin loss on symmetric encoding features?
relevant_context: We utilize a non-linear projection P to transform the features before calculating the distance in margin loss, which aims to enhance the quality of the learned features.
We hypothesize that directly applying metric learning to segmentation features might lead to information loss and diminish the model‚Äôs effectiveness.
For example, some asymmetries in CT images are non-pathological and may stem from variations in the patient‚Äôs head positioning and posing, yet they are beneficial for segmentation.
Utilizing a non-linear projection can filter out such irrelevant information from the metric learning process, ensuring it is preserved in the features used for segmentation.
final_answer: The non-linear projection head is inserted so that the margin loss is applied to a purified feature space: it filters out non-pathological asymmetries (e.g. pose or angle variations) that would otherwise corrupt the contrastive signal, while preserving those features critical for segmentation.

question: What motivates balancing accuracy loss and consistency loss during diversification training?
relevant_context: For each training epoch of the stacked U-Net, two paths, P‚ÇÅ and P‚ÇÇ, are randomly selected for each input batch, yielding two separate predictions, ≈∑‚ÇÅ and ≈∑‚ÇÇ. The loss function is then augmented with a regularization term that addresses the discrepancy between these two predictions, in addition to the standard error term that measures the deviation between the ground truth y and the prediction ≈∑.
In this manuscript, two losses are balanced using the coefficient Œª. For simplicity, Œª is set to 1, but it can be adjusted according to user requirements.

During back-propagation, only the candidate blocks along the active path, P‚ÇÇ, responsible for the prediction ≈∑‚ÇÇ, are updated. This focused updating approach helps in stabilizing the learning process and refining the model‚Äôs performance by iteratively adjusting only the actively involved blocks, illustrated in Algorithm 1.
final_answer: Balancing the accuracy loss (deviation from ground truth) with the consistency loss (discrepancy between two model predictions) is motivated by the need to diversify and regularize the ensemble without sacrificing predictive performance. By weighting both terms, the model is encouraged to remain accurate while also maintaining agreement among its diversified sub-models, leading to a more stable optimization and improved overall performance.

question: How does Inter Cluster Sample compute Monte Carlo UCB scores using cluster variance estimates?
relevant_context: Carpentier et al. [49] suggested an approach to progressively estimate variances. This method involves calculating the Monte Carlo Upper Confidence Bound (MC-UCB) for each cluster (treated as an ‚Äòarm‚Äô in a multi-armed bandit problem) and selecting the arm with the highest upper bound for subsequent sampling.

At current search round t, the MC-UCB score of cluster k is computed as follows: where N_k is the cluster size, n^{(t)}_k is the number of points sampled in the previous round, s_k is the empirical standard deviation within each cluster, and a is a hyper-parameter.
final_answer: At each round t, AcTracer treats each cluster as an arm and computes a Monte Carlo Upper Confidence Bound (MC-UCB) score by combining the cluster‚Äôs estimated standard deviation s_k, the total cluster size N_k and the number of points n^{(t)}_k already sampled in that cluster, along with a hyper-parameter a. The cluster with the highest MC-UCB score is then chosen for the next sample.

2.  Keep track, for each cluster \(i\), of  
   ‚Äì \(|C_i|\): the total number of points in that cluster,

   ‚Äì \(\hat\sigma_i\): the empirical standard deviation of the performance metric over the \(k_i\) sampled points.  
3.  At round \(t\), fix your failure‚Äêprobability parameter  
   \[
     \delta \;=\;\frac{2}{t^2}\quad(\text{since our metric is bounded, this choice of }\delta\text{ gives a valid high‚Äêprobability bound).}
   \]
4.  Compute the Monte‚ÄêCarlo UCB index for cluster \(i\) as
   \[
     \mathrm{MC\text{-}UCB}_i(t)
     \;=\;
     |C_i|\;\hat\sigma_i\;\sqrt{\frac{2\,\ln\bigl(2/\delta\bigr)}{\,k_i\,}}
     \;=\;
     |C_i|\;\hat\sigma_i\;\sqrt{\frac{2\,\ln\bigl(t^2\bigr)}{\,k_i\,}}\,. 
   \]
5.  Pick the cluster with the largest \(\mathrm{MC\text{-}UCB}_i(t)\) to draw your next sample from‚Äîthis automatically balances sampling more in large clusters and in clusters whose within‚Äêcluster variance is still poorly known.

In short, the red box is simply the plug‚Äêin UCB rule of Carpentier et al., where the ‚Äúbonus‚Äù term grows with the cluster size and empirical standard deviation, and shrinks as more points in that cluster are observed.

question: How does Intra Cluster Sample minimize discrepancy between sampled examples and LLM Confidence Distribution within clusters?
relevant_context: Our intra-cluster sample is guided by the output confidence of the LLMs. While the internal states represent models‚Äô knowledge, the output confidence reveals more information about models‚Äô decisions.

Our goal in this stage is to maintain the confidence distribution of the sample drawn to be as close as possible to the distribution of the entire cluster, aiming for an intra-cluster level unbiased sampling.

This is achieved by selecting candidate sample points that greedily minimize the distance between the confidence distributions of the sampled points and the entire cluster. For measuring the distance between these distributions, the two-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov test and the Wasserstein distance are applied.

question: How does cluster search‚Äôs adaptive sampling relate to the elbow-point heuristic in unsupervised clustering?
relevant_context: Instead, the relationship between cluster number and inertia is more of a trade-off, where the elbow point of the cluster num-inertia curve is a widely used heuristic for appropriate cluster number search.

In our study, we employ the Kneedle algorithm to automatically identify the elbow point as the proper number of clusters. To enhance the efficiency of the search process, we leverage adaptive sampling to intensively sample cluster number-inertia pairs in regions of rapid function change.
final_answer: Cluster search‚Äôs adaptive sampling concentrates its limited evaluations on the region of the cluster-number vs. inertia curve where inertia drops most sharply‚Äîthe elbow region. By sampling more intensively around this rapid-change area, it efficiently finds the elbow point (via the Kneedle algorithm) that indicates the optimal number of clusters.

\footnotesize2‚Éù: An automated search mechanism to identify a suitable number of clusters corresponding to a given LLM and test data. The geometry structure obtained through the clustering algorithm partitions the input test spaces for more efficient sampling.
\footnotesize3‚Éù: An intra-cluster and inter-cluster sampling strategy to actively select the next data point for labelling.

Here ‚ÄúCluster Search‚Äù is the step in which we decide how many clusters to use (i.e. we are searching for the knee or ‚Äúelbow‚Äù of the k-inertia curve), and ‚ÄúAdaptive Sampling‚Äù is the trick we use to find that elbow quickly.  Concretely:

 1.  We know that if you plot the total within-cluster inertia versus number of clusters k, you get a convex, strictly decreasing curve, and that the ‚Äúright‚Äù k is often taken to be the elbow (i.e. the point of maximum curvature in that curve).

 2.  Rather than evaluating inertia for every possible k (which would be wasteful), we use adaptive sampling to choose the next k at which to compute inertia based on where the curve is changing most rapidly.

 3.  Once we have a handful of (k, inertia) pairs in those high-curvature regions, we feed them into the Kneedle algorithm to pinpoint the elbow.

In other words, the ‚ÄúAdaptive Sampling‚Äù inside our ‚ÄúCluster Search‚Äù module is simply a way to home in on the elbow of the inertia‚Äìk curve with far fewer evaluations than a brute-force sweep, yet still recover the classic elbow-point heuristic that balances compactness (low inertia) against over-splitting (too many clusters).

question: How does Eq-Frame model leverage group equivariant network frameworks for canonical yaw frame estimation?
relevant_context: Section 4.1: ‚ÄúWe see that choosing f(g¬∑x)=g¬∑f(x) satisfies this equality, leveraging the fact that œÜ is a homomorphism, i.e. œÜ(g‚ÇÅg‚ÇÇ)=œÜ(g‚ÇÅ)œÜ(g‚ÇÇ). This equality puts a constraint on the neural network that estimates f, namely f(g¬∑x)=g¬∑f(x), i.e. f must be equivariant with respect to group actions by elements from G. Since G is a subgroup of O(3) we also say that f must be subequivariant with respect to G.‚Äù

Section 4.3: ‚ÄúInspired by Villar et al. (2021), we design our frame network to learn universally G equivariant outputs from invariant features alongside 2D vector features. We convert the sequence of N IMU measurements into S scalar features and V vector features. While we process scalar features with multilayer perceptrons and standard 1-D convolutions, we process vector features with specific linear and convolution layers, and combine scalar and vector features with specialized non-linear layers.‚Äù
final_answer: Eq-Frame enforces that its yaw‚Äêframe predictor f commutes with every rotation or reflection in the subgroup G of transformations preserving gravity: f(g¬∑x)=g¬∑f(x). To do so it decomposes gravity‚Äêaligned IMU readings into G‚Äêinvariant scalars and G‚Äêequivariant 2D vectors, then processes them with G‚Äêequivariant linear layers (Eq-L), G-equivariant 1D convolutions (Eq-Conv) over time, and gated nonlinearities‚Äîeach designed so that their weights satisfy the equivariance constraint WœÜ(g)=œÜ(g)W. This guarantees that the estimated canonical yaw frame transforms correctly under all rotations and reflections around the gravity axis, yielding a frame estimate that generalizes across arbitrary IMU orientations.

question: How does the equivariant non-linear layer integrate scalar and vector features while preserving equivariance?
relevant_context: Previous works (Weiler et al., 2018; Weiler & Cesa, 2019) propose various nonlinearities such as norm-nonlinearity, tensor-product nonlinearity, and gated nonlinearity for SO(2) and O(2) equivariance in an equivariant convolutional way; while Deng et al. (2021) applies per‚Äêpoint nonlinearity for vector features only. Since we already apply convolutions over time we simply apply a non‚Äêlinearity pointwise. Unlike Deng et al. (2021), we need to mix scalar and vector features and thus adapt the gated nonlinearity (Weiler et al., 2018) to pointwise nonlinearity.

Specifically, for C vector and C scalar features, we concatenate the norm features of the vectors with the scalar features. We run a single MLP with an output of size 2C, and split it into new norm features r and new activations a which we modulate with a non‚Äêlinearity œÉ. Finally, we rescale the original vector features according to the new norm: v' = v ‚äô (r ¬∑ œÉ(a)), where ‚äô denotes element‚Äêwise multiplication and the concatenation was along the feature dimension.
final_answer: The equivariant non-linear layer first computes the norms of each vector feature and concatenates these invariant norms with the scalar features. This concatenated vector is fed through a shared MLP whose 2C outputs are split into two C-dimensional vectors: one r of "new norms" and one a of gating activations. A pointwise non-linearity œÉ is applied to a, and then each original vector feature v is rescaled by the element-wise product r¬∑œÉ(a). Because r and œÉ(a) are computed from invariant quantities (scalars and norms), and scaling commutes with rotations, the resulting transformation of the vector features remains equivariant.

    ‚Ä¢  A set of *new norms* for each 2D vector.

In that way the equivariant non‚Äêlinear layer fuses the scalar and vector streams without ever losing equivariance.

question: How does incremental addition of views influence initial PnP pose estimates from cube probe?
relevant_context: Incremental pose optimization. We employ an incremental pose optimization approach, introducing a new image into the training loop at fixed intervals. Given the input images and corresponding masks of the calibration object, the first image is designated as the reference image. Multiple projection views around the object are sampled to acquire mask images, and the view with the best matching mask is selected as the initial pose for the first frame. For each newly added frame, we first compute 2D correspondences with the previous image using SuperPoint and SuperGlue. The matching pixels in the image cast rays to locate corresponding 3D points on the object, leveraging the optimized pose for precise surface positioning. This forms 2D-3D correspondences between the newly added image and the object, allowing the PnP with RANSAC to calculate the initial pose of the new image.

Incremental pose optimization improves initial poses for new frames by using the optimized poses from previous frames, making overall pose alignment easier. Removing this strategy results in a significant drop in model performance.
final_answer: By adding views one at a time and using the already‚Äêoptimized poses from earlier frames to establish 2D‚Äì3D correspondences, the cube‚Äêprobe PnP initialization for each new view becomes progressively more accurate and stable.

Concretely, every time we ‚Äúadd a view incrementally‚Äù (mask‚ÇÅ), we match its keypoints against the immediately preceding, already-registered view, lift those 2D matches to 3D surface points on the probe (using the last view‚Äôs optimized pose), and then run PnP + RANSAC to get a fresh initialization for the new frame‚Äôs camera (mask‚ÇÇ).  In other words, the red-boxed ‚Äúadd views incrementally‚Äù module supplies exactly the 2D‚Äì3D correspondences and warm-start pose that the blue-boxed ‚ÄúPnP pose init‚Äù needs to succeed even in very sparse, feature-poor scenes.

Here the red‚Äêboxed ‚Äúmask‚Äù is simply the fact that we always start our SDF with a little cube (i.e. ‚Äúcube init‚Äù).  That choice brings two related limitations when you try to morph very complicated probe shapes:

  1. fixed, coarse domain and resolution  
     ‚Äì Because our explicit SDF is a non‚Äêlearnable voxel grid pegged to that initial cube‚Äôs bounds, any part of the true object that protrudes outside (or nestles into very thin or concave regions) can‚Äôt be faithfully represented.  
     ‚Äì Fine geometric detail finer than the cube‚Äôs voxel pitch is simply out of reach.

  2. large, highly non‚Äêlinear deformations

Under only a handful of views this strain often leads to degenerate solutions or ‚Äúcollapsed‚Äù geometry, because the network has to both invent new topology and respect the rigid boundaries of the cube‚Äôs grid.

In practice this means that while cube‚Äêinit SDFs work great for mostly convex, blob-like probes, they begin to fail (losing thin parts, suffering self‚Äêintersections or collapsed regions) as the probe‚Äôs true shape departs further from the starting cube.

question: What ethical concerns might using generic everyday pose probes raise in privacy-sensitive scene reconstructions?
final_answer: Unanswerable
masked_question: What ethical concerns might using generic everyday [mask1] raise in privacy-sensitive scene reconstructions?
caption: Figure 2: Method overview. We leverage generic objects in few-view input images as pose probes. The method does not introduce extra burden but successfully facilitates pose estimation in feature-sparse scenes.
response:
First, let‚Äôs identify the masked term by aligning the diagram with the text:

‚Äì In the figure the red‚Äêboxed item is labelled ‚Äúprobe poses,‚Äù and throughout the paper they talk about using ‚Äúgeneric everyday objects‚Äù (e.g. a Coke can or a box) as pose probes.  
‚Äì So the full phrase is ‚Äúgeneric everyday objects.‚Äù

Now, what ethical concerns might arise from using generic everyday objects as calibration probes in privacy-sensitive scene reconstructions?

Chain of thought:

1. The method deliberately exploits commonplace items already present in a scene‚Äîcups, cans, boxes, toys‚Äîas built-in calibration targets to recover camera poses and build a 3D model.  
2. Because these objects are ubiquitous and unobtrusive, someone could slip into a private space (a home, office, or other sensitive environment), snap just a handful of photos, and reconstruct the geometry‚Äîand potentially the appearance‚Äîof that space without the occupants‚Äô knowledge.  
3. Even if faces and people are masked out, detailed geometry of the interior (furniture layouts, personal effects, artwork) could be reverse-engineered, revealing sensitive information about habits, possessions, or vulnerabilities.  
4. Such reconstructions can be stored, shared, or analyzed further (e.g. for target profiling, real-estate spying, burglary scouting), all without explicit consent from the space‚Äôs owner.  
5. Finally, the automatic segmentation (SAM) and self-supervised refinement make it trivial for a malicious actor to do this at scale‚Äîharvesting everyday objects as ‚Äúfree‚Äù calibration markers without alerting anyone.

Answer:
Using generic everyday objects as pose-probes makes it stealthily easy to turn ordinary snapshots of a private environment into a full 3D reconstruction. That in turn raises serious privacy and consent issues‚Äîpeople could have their homes or offices digitized without permission, exposing personal layouts, belongings, or other sensitive details for misuse by third parties.

question: What biases might LLM-based Prompt introduce in spatial anomaly localization scenarios?
final_answer: Unanswerable
masked_question: What biases might [mask1] introduce in spatial anomaly localization scenarios?
caption: Figure 2. The pipeline of our proposed STPrompt.
response:
First, let us be precise about what ‚Äú[mask1]‚Äù is.  In the red‚Äêboxed region of Fig. 2 the authors are calling out the ‚ÄúLLM-based Prompt‚Äù module.  Concretely, at test time they query a large language model for two sets of short captions:

  ‚Ä¢  A small list of ‚Äúnormal‚Äù background descriptions (e.g. ‚Äúa picture of road,‚Äù ‚Äúa picture of grass,‚Äù ‚Äúa picture of chair,‚Äù etc.)  
  ‚Ä¢  A set of ‚Äúabnormal‚Äù descriptions generated by prompting the LLM for synonyms or paraphrases of each high-level anomaly class (e.g. ‚Äúpeople knockout someone,‚Äù ‚Äúsomeone lying on the ground,‚Äù ‚Äúsomeone ignite fire,‚Äù ‚Ä¶)  

They then embed all of those phrases with CLIP and do a patch-to-text matching over the frame patches to build a spatial heatmap of likely ‚Äúabnormal‚Äù regions.

Because those text prompts come directly out of an LLM, they carry all of the LLM‚Äôs implicit assumptions and gaps in coverage.  In practice this can introduce three main types of bias into the spatial localization:

  1.  **Concept‚ÄêCoverage Bias**  
     ‚Äì  The LLM‚Äôs idea of what ‚Äúnormal‚Äù looks like is drawn from its massive but skewed web-text pretraining.  If it never saw, say, an overhead security-camera image of a subway platform at midnight, it may well omit that as a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù background and end up marking it anomalous.  
     ‚Äì  Likewise, its paraphrases for ‚Äúfighting‚Äù or ‚Äúarson‚Äù may miss less common or culturally-specific variants of those events, so genuine anomalies never match any abnormal prompt.  

  2.  **Language/Cultural Bias**  
     ‚Äì  The phrases the LLM produces reflect the cultural and topical slant of its training data.  It might overemphasize the kinds of indoor furniture or roadway vocabulary seen in blockbuster film scripts and underrepresent, say, rural or warehouse backdrops.  
     ‚Äì  This language bias translates directly into over- and under-sensitive patch retrieval: regions matching well-represented prompts get boosted; under-represented but perfectly normal areas get penalized (false positives).  

  3.  **Selection & Synonymy Bias**  
     ‚Äì  By choosing a handful of LLM-generated ‚Äúnormal‚Äù/‚Äúabnormal‚Äù captions, the authors implicitly pick a small subspace of all possible valid descriptions.  Any patch whose true content falls outside that subspace will tend to be ranked poorly.  
     ‚Äì  If the LLM leans heavily on one synonym (e.g. ‚Äúpeople knock out someone‚Äù vs. ‚Äúperson strikes another‚Äù), one phrasing may align well while the other does not‚Äîeven though they mean the same thing.  That inconsistency produces spurious hot-spots or misses real ones.  

In short, the ‚ÄúLLM-based Prompt‚Äù unit imports the LLM‚Äôs semantic priors‚Äîits skewed concept coverage, cultural slants, and idiosyncratic choice of synonyms‚Äîdirectly into the patch-level retrieval.  Those biases translate into spatial localization that is:

  ‚Ä¢  Overly confident on familiar, well-represented backgrounds or wordings  
  ‚Ä¢  Prone to false alarms in perfectly normal but under-described scene types  
  ‚Ä¢  Prone to misses whenever the anomaly manifests in a form the LLM didn‚Äôt enumerate  

All of these are specific instances of distributional and semantic bias introduced by feeding LLM-generated text directly into a vision-language patch retrieval pipeline.

question: What alternative mechanisms to TopK could enhance robustness in variable-length anomaly detection?

masked_question: What alternative mechanisms to [mask1] could enhance robustness in variable-length anomaly detection?
caption: Figure 2. The pipeline of our proposed STPrompt.
response:
First, let‚Äôs be very clear about what ‚Äú[mask1]‚Äù is in the figure.  If you look at the red‚Äêboxed module on the right‚Äêhand side of Fig. 2 under ‚ÄúBinary Classifier ‚Üí video‚Äêlevel binary label,‚Äù you‚Äôll see it says ‚ÄúTop-K.‚Äù  In other words, STPrompt‚Äôs classification branch aggregates its frame‚Äêlevel anomaly scores by picking the top K most anomalous frames and then applies a loss on those K scores.  

Now the question asks: ‚ÄúWhat alternative mechanisms to Top-K could enhance robustness in variable‚Äêlength anomaly detection?‚Äù  In other words, instead of always taking a fixed number K of highest‚Äêscoring frames, what other pooling or aggregation strategies might we plug in to make the system more stable when videos have very different lengths or very different densities of anomalies?  

Here is a short chain of thought:

1.   **Why might fixed-K Top-K be brittle?**  
     - If one video is 100 frames long and another is 10‚Äâ000 frames long, ‚ÄúTop-K‚Äù might overemphasize outliers in one case and underemphasize them in the other.  
     - If a video has a single brief glitch versus an extended anomalous segment, the same fixed K may either miss that single glitch or may overweight background in the longer case.  

2.   **What properties do we want in an alternative?**  
     - It should adapt to the length of the video or to the density of anomalies.  
     - It should be learnable (so the network can decide which frames matter most).  
     - It should be robust to noisy high scores that come from background or detector jitter.  

3.   **Candidate replacements for Top-K:**  
   a)  **Attention‚Äêbased MIL pooling** (a ‚Äúgated attention‚Äù or ‚Äúsoft attention‚Äù)  
       - Introduce a small network that, for each frame‚Äêlevel feature, predicts a scalar attention weight Œ±·µ¢.  
       - Aggregate via \( \sum_i Œ±_i‚Äâs_i \) (where s·µ¢ is the anomaly score of frame i).  
       - The network is trained jointly so that it learns to focus on true anomaly frames and downweight spurious high scores.  
   b)  **Ratio-based Top-p pooling**  
       - Instead of fixing K, pick the top p percent of frames (e.g. top 5%), so that the number of frames automatically scales with video length.  
   c)  **Robust statistic pooling**  
       - Use a trimmed‚Äêmean or median of the top X% of scores (e.g. drop the top and bottom Œµ% and take the mean of the rest) to guard against both spurious spikes and outlier suppression.  
   d)  **NetVLAD or VLAD-style pooling**  
       - Cluster the frame embeddings into G ‚Äúvisual words‚Äù and then pool a VLAD descriptor over the entire video, turning a variable-length sequence into a fixed-size vector.  
       - A downstream classifier then works on that fixed vector.  
   e)  **Transformer-based set aggregator**  
       - Feed the whole sequence of frame embeddings into a small self-attention module (a Set-Transformer or one or two layers of Transformer).  
       - Use its learned [CLS] token (or a learned pooling token) as a summary embedding and attach your binary classifier to that.  
   f)  **Learnable rank pooling**  
       - Parameterize a smooth rank‚Äêbased pooling (e.g. ‚ÄúLogSumExp pooling‚Äù or ‚Äúsoft‚Äêmax pooling‚Äù):  
           score = (1/Œ≤) ¬∑ log ‚àë·µ¢ exp(Œ≤ ¬∑ s·µ¢).  
       - As Œ≤‚Üí‚àû it approximates max‚Äêpooling; for moderate Œ≤ it blends max and average.  Œ≤ can be a learned parameter.  

Any of these alternatives can adapt to the actual content and length of the video, learn to suppress background noise or spurious high‚Äêscore frames, and thus often yield more robust anomaly detection when the original Top-K may over‚Äê or under-represent anomalies.

question: What motivates integrating Spatial Attention Aggregation with frame features before Temporal Adapter processing?
relevant_context: Although we explicitly disentangle WSVADL into two independent tasks, i.e., temporal anomaly detection and spatial anomaly detection, for the temporal anomaly detection task, we still require the critical spatial local anomalies as assistance information. This is because potential spatial anomalies can eliminate the noise effect caused by the irrelevant backgrounds, after all, most anomalies may occupy a small spatial region.

No matter how the spatial region of abnormal events changes, these two features, i.e., the global frame feature and the aggregated spatial feature, can extract key abnormal information from the local and global perspectives. In other words, they are complementary.

question: What advantage arises from combining Binary Classifier outputs with MIL-Align alignment for video-level labeling?
relevant_context: Throughout the whole process, we devise two modules to encourage the model to focus on anomalies from the spatial and temporal dimensions, which are illustrated in the following sections.

Inspired by the pioneer work VadCLIP (Wu et al., 2024b), we also introduce a dual-branch framework, namely, classification branch and alignment branch. Specifically, given a video V, we employ a frozen image encoder of CLIP to extract the frame-level feature f, where T is the length of video V, and d is the feature dimension. Then these features are fed into two branches after a series of information enhancements, classification branch is to directly predict the anomaly confidence p_b by a binary classifier, another align branch is to compute the anomaly category probability p_a by means of the image-to-concept alignment. With p_b and p_a in hands, we adopt the typical TopK and the recent MIL-Align strategies to compute the video-level anomaly prediction and category prediction, respectively, these predictions are subsequently used to calculate losses and provide data support for model optimization.
final_answer: By using both the binary classifier‚Äôs TopK-based anomaly score and the MIL-Align category alignment, the model obtains two complementary video-level labels‚Äîone indicating whether an anomaly occurs and one specifying its category. This dual-branch supervision enriches the training signals and leads to more robust anomaly detection and classification under weak video-level labels.

2.  In the blue box sits the A-Branch ‚ÄúMIL-Align‚Äù module, which aligns each frame (or patch) feature against text prompts for all anomaly classes and then uses a MIL-style top-k pooling to yield a per-class probability for the entire video.  
3.  If you use only the C-Branch you get a good yes/no anomaly signal but no idea which kind of anomaly.  If you use only the A-Branch you get class probabilities but they can be noisy when the video actually contains no anomaly.

   - A reliable binary ‚Äúis there an anomaly?‚Äù gate (so you don‚Äôt hallucinate classes when nothing is wrong)  
   - A semantically grounded class prediction when there *is* an anomaly  
   - Stronger, complementary gradient signals during training (binary+multiclass), which stabilizes learning under only video-level supervision  
5.  In practice this means more accurate video‚Äêlevel labels (both presence/absence and category) without ever having to collect frame- or pixel-level annotations.

By fusing the TopK‚Äêbased binary‚Äêconfidence output (red box) with the MIL-Align category‚Äêalignment output (blue box), the model simultaneously learns ‚Äúis there an anomaly?‚Äù and ‚Äúif so, which kind?‚Äù from only video-level labels.  The binary branch keeps class predictions from firing on normal clips, the alignment branch injects semantic category information when anomalies are present, and together they deliver far more precise video-level anomaly detection and classification than either branch alone.

question: How does the multi-scale transformer block coordinate scale-specific self-attention maps to maintain consistent semantic context?

Finally, we perform attention map activation and concatenate three attention features with different scales to generate the first stage feature H1.

It computes independent dot-product self-attention maps for each scale, applies the same activation to each, and finally concatenates these three scale-specific attention outputs. A multi-scale feed-forward network and a residual connection then fuse the concatenated result with the original input, ensuring that although attention is performed at multiple scales, the overall semantic context remains consistent across the combined feature.

question: How do GPM and LRM collaboratively optimize global relationships and local details in COS?

Concretely:

 2.  For every synthetic report, we draw the same fixed number of entities from each of the first four buckets, plus a fixed number from the anatomy bucket.

The LLM generates synthetic reports containing exactly those entities, producing a dataset whose clinical concepts are evenly distributed.

At every iteration, class-conditional query features (‚Äúprompts‚Äù) are then drawn by sampling from the specific Gaussian mixture corresponding to each target class. These sampled prompts drive the model to predict per-class saliency masks, which are used to extract class-specific audio and visual features via masked average pooling. Answer  
By fitting a GMM over the joint‚Äêmodal mask embeddings for each class, the model learns the full, multimodal distribution of ‚Äúwhat a pink (cello), purple (violin), etc.‚Äù embedding looks like.  During training we then sample new prompt vectors directly from the Gaussian component assigned to each ground‚Äêtruth class.  Those sampled class‚Äêconditional prompts are used to query the decoder, generate class‚Äêspecific saliency masks, and extract per‚Äêclass audio/visual feature regions for the supervised InfoNCE contrastive loss.

question: Suggest alternatives to GMM for enhancing distribution modelling of class-conditional prompts.

masked_question: Suggest alternatives to [mask1] for enhancing distribution modelling of class-conditional prompts.
caption: Figure 1: Comparing conventional AVS methods [7, 13] with our CPM approach, CPM inherits the class-agnostic query from transformer-based methods and integrates class-conditional prompts sampled from the learned joint-modal data distribution to achieve three objectives: 1) learn disentangled audio partitioning, 2) facilitate semantic-guided object identification, and 3) promote more explicit audio-visual contrastive learning.
response:
First, let us restate what ‚Äú‚Äã[mask1]‚Äã‚Äù is referring to in the figure and in the text:

‚Äì In ¬ß3.2.1 (‚ÄúClass Conditional Distribution Modelling‚Äù) the authors say ‚Äú‚ÄãWe adopt the Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs) as such generative model‚Ä¶, which improves the intra-class variability and increases robustness to class imbalances‚Ä¶‚Äã.‚Äù  
‚Äì In the red-boxed inset of Fig. 1 you can see the ‚ÄúGMM‚Äù node whose outputs are sampled to produce class-conditional prompts.

So the question really asks:

  ‚ÄúIf you didn‚Äôt want to use a GMM to model the joint-modal mask-embedding distribution, what other distribution-modelling techniques could you plug in instead, in order to sample class-conditional prompts?‚Äù  

Here is a short chain-of-thought followed by a list of concrete alternatives:

1. **Why think beyond GMM?**  
   ‚Äì GMMs are a classical, parametric way to model a multi-modal embedding distribution, but they assume mixtures of Gaussians and full-covariance estimation can be costly in high dimensions.  
   ‚Äì Modern deep generative models can capture more complex, highly non-Gaussian densities; they can interpolate smoothly between modes and can scale to very high dimensions.

2. **What properties do we need?**  
   ‚Äì A model that, once trained, lets us sample diverse but class-consistent embedding vectors (‚Äúprompts‚Äù).  
   ‚Äì It should handle multi-modality within each class (e.g. a violin sound under different timbres, intensities, room acoustics).  
   ‚Äì Ideally it updates online or incrementally as the underlying transformer-mask embeddings evolve.

3. **Families of replacements:**

   A. **Variational Auto-Encoders (VAEs)**  
      ‚Äì Train a conditional VAE per class (or a single CVAE with a one-hot class code).  
      ‚Äì At sampling time you condition on class label and draw from the learned latent Gaussian, then decode to a prompt embedding.  
      ‚Äì Pros: scalable, amortized inference, can capture complex manifolds.

   B. **Normalizing Flows**  
      ‚Äì E.g. RealNVP, Glow, Masked Autoregressive Flow (MAF).  
      ‚Äì These learn an invertible mapping from a simple base distribution (e.g. N(0,I)) to the mask-embedding space.  
      ‚Äì You attach a class-condition either via concatenation or via FiLM layers.  
      ‚Äì Pros: exact likelihoods, flexible multi-modal densities, cheap sampling.

   C. **Conditional Generative Adversarial Networks (cGANs)**  
      ‚Äì Learn a generator \(G(z,c)\) that, given noise \(z\sim N(0,I)\) and class-code \(c\), produces an embedding in the prompt space.  
      ‚Äì Pros: often sharper samples, very flexible; cons: training stability.

   D. **Diffusion / Score-Based Models**  
      ‚Äì Train a small conditional diffusion model in the embedding space: start from noise and iteratively denoise towards a class-specific prompt.  
      ‚Äì Pros: state-of-the-art density modelling; cons: slower sampling.

   E. **Non-parametric Density Estimation**  
      ‚Äì Kernel Density Estimation (Parzen windows) over a memory bank of embeddings per class.  
      ‚Äì At sample time draw a random memory point and perturb it by a small Gaussian.  
      ‚Äì Pros: very simple; cons: scales poorly in high D, choice of kernel bandwidth is critical.

   F. **Dirichlet-Process / Bayesian Nonparametrics**  
      ‚Äì Replace a fixed-K GMM with an infinite-mixture model, automatically inferring the number of modes in each class.  
      ‚Äì Pros: flexible number of components; cons: more complicated inference (Gibbs, variational Bayes).

   G. **Neural Mixture-of-Experts**  
      ‚Äì A small routing network decides which expert network (or which sub-distribution) to sample from for a given class.  
      ‚Äì Pros: can condition on context beyond class label; cons: more moving parts.

4. **Concrete suggestion**  
   ‚Äì If you want to stay ‚Äúlight,‚Äù swap the GMM for a **conditional VAE**: you collect mask embeddings for class k, train a class-conditioned encoder/decoder that maps them to a low-dim Gaussian latent, then at each CPM iteration you sample \(z\sim N(0,I)\), decode \(\hat e = \text{Decoder}(z, k)\) and use \(\hat e\) as your prompt.  
   ‚Äì If you need more expressive power, use a **conditional Glow** or **MAF** in place of the GMM ‚Äî in practice you would fit the flow to the same memory bank of embeddings and then draw as many prompts per class as you like with trivial sampling.

All of these approaches would slot into the pipeline exactly where ‚ÄúGMM‚Äù is now, replacing the red-boxed module with a different generative modelling block.

question: What are potential limitations of bypassing bipartite matching with fixed GT assignment?
final_answer: Unanswerable
masked_question: What are potential limitations of bypassing [mask1] with fixed GT assignment?
caption: Figure 1: Comparing conventional AVS methods [7, 13] with our CPM approach, CPM inherits the class-agnostic query from transformer-based methods and integrates class-conditional prompts sampled from the learned joint-modal data distribution to achieve three objectives: 1) learn disentangled audio partitioning, 2) facilitate semantic-guided object identification, and 3) promote more explicit audio-visual contrastive learning.
response:
Here is a step-by-step breakdown of why blindly ‚Äúhard-wiring‚Äù each prompt to a fixed ground-truth (GT) slot‚Äîi.e. completely skipping the Hungarian bipartite matching and simply saying ‚Äúprompt 1 always means class A,‚Äù ‚Äúprompt 2 always means class B,‚Äù and so on‚Äîcan backfire in practice:

1. loss of flexibility in the number of objects  
   ‚Äì In the usual bipartite set‚Äêmatching you can cope with images that have 0, 1 or many instances of a class by simply matching whichever queries the model has ‚Äúdiscovered.‚Äù  
   ‚Äì With a fixed GT-assignment you have to reserve exactly one (or some predetermined number of) query slots per class.  If an image has more objects of class X than you allotted queries, you can‚Äôt assign them.  If it has fewer, some prompts will be ‚Äúleft dangling‚Äù and contribute noise.

2. brittle to missing or noisy annotations  
   ‚Äì Real datasets often contain annotation omissions or label noise.  Under bipartite matching the model can in principle ignore spurious GT boxes or ‚Äúdrop‚Äù a missing object by assigning it to the no‚Äêobject null class.  
   ‚Äì With fixed assignments, every prompt must find its exact partner in the GT.  If that ground‚Äìtruth label is wrong or missing, you force the model to learn from pure noise.

3. reduced permutation‚Äêinvariance and generalization  
   ‚Äì The Hungarian matcher intrinsically respects that queries are permutation‚Äêinvariant: you don‚Äôt care which query gets which object, as long as each object is covered exactly once.  This encourages the model to discover objects in any order.  
   ‚Äì A hard-wired assignment breaks that principle: the model learns a brittle ordering (‚Äúobject A always lives in slot 3‚Äù), which rarely transfers when object counts, aspect ratios or backgrounds shift at test time.

4. inability to handle variable instance counts per class  
   ‚Äì Some images may have two violins and no cellos, others one cello and three violins.  A fixed one-query-per-class scheme cannot adapt to those per‚Äêimage count variations.  
   ‚Äì Bipartite matching, by contrast, simply matches as many queries to GT objects as needed and dumps the rest as ‚Äúno‚Äêobject.‚Äù

5. over-constraint and reduced robustness  
   ‚Äì By forcing an exact prompt‚áÑGT mapping you inject a very strong ‚Äúcurriculum‚Äù but you also remove the model‚Äôs ability to self-correct.  If during early training the model‚Äôs ‚Äúslot 2‚Äù is badly initialized, that error will persist and hurt convergence rather than being ‚Äúre-matched‚Äù away by the Hungarian solver.

In short, while fixed GT assignments can stabilize one piece of the training pipeline, they do so at the cost of flexibility, robustness to noisy or variable annotations, and the permutation‚Äêinvariant object discovery that makes transformer-based set predictors so powerful.

question: What motivates Self-Validating Filtering to dynamically adjust denoising steps?
relevant_context: While our approach so far adaptively controls the number of token embeddings to be updated, it sometimes lacks flexibility in preserving the original generation capabilities for content outside the target concept. Recent observations (Kim et al., 2024a; Ban et al., 2024a) suggest that different denoising timesteps in T2I models contribute unevenly to generating toxic or undesirable content.

Based on this insight, we propose a self-validating filtering mechanism during the denoising steps of the diffusion model that automatically adjusts the number of denoising timesteps conditioned on the obtained embedding.
final_answer: It is motivated by the finding that different denoising timesteps have uneven influence on the creation of toxic or undesirable content, so dynamically adjusting when to apply the filtered embeddings lets the method strengthen filtering for unsafe prompts while preserving quality for safe prompts.

SAFREE adaptively controls the filtering strength in an input-dependent manner, which also regulates a latent-level re-attention mechanism. In this way, it tightens the reins when the prompt still looks unsafe and backs off when it‚Äôs already been cleansed, preserving as much of the original model‚Äôs generative power as possible.

question: What is the reasoning for applying Selective Orthogonal Projection after Toxic Token Detection?
relevant_context: However, directly removing or replacing these tokens with irrelevant ones, such as random tokens or replacing the token embeddings with null embeddings, disrupts the coherence between words and sentences, compromising the quality of the generated image to the safe input prompt, particularly when the prompt is unrelated to the toxic concepts.

To address this, we propose projecting the detected token embeddings into a space orthogonal to the toxic concept subspace while keeping them within the input space to ensure that the integrity of the original prompt is preserved as much as possible.
final_answer: Selective Orthogonal Projection is used to eliminate the toxic concept associations from the detected tokens in the embedding space while preserving the semantic coherence and overall integrity of the original prompt, thereby avoiding the quality degradation that would occur if tokens were simply removed or replaced.

question: What reasoning underlies combining Gram matrices and MLPs for weather-aware feature extraction?
relevant_context: Weather variations can be viewed as distinct image ‚Äústyles‚Äù, which are inherently decoupled from the image content.
The Gram matrix, which represents correlations within feature maps, is commonly used to define image styles.
Yet, the original form of the Gram matrix fails in the context of multi-weather restoration, as it represents artistic styles rather than weather-relevant features.
To address this, we append trainable projection layers‚Äîmulti-layer perceptrons (MLPs)‚Äîon top of the vanilla Gram matrix, to learn weather-specific ‚Äústyle‚Äù.
final_answer: The authors treat each weather degradation as an image ‚Äústyle‚Äù independent of content, so they use the Gram matrix to capture feature-correlation statistics (style) and then place MLPs on top to learn to map those raw style descriptors into weather-specific embeddings. This combination lets the network decouple weather effects from scene content and produce a compact, learned weather-aware feature vector.

question: What is the rationale for generating depthwise convolution kernels via HyperMLP for local adaptivity?
relevant_context: Since vanilla Transformer architectures lack inductive biases expressive of local pixel interactions, we add a depthwise convolution layer between the two MLPs in each feed-forward network (FFN) in the Transformer blocks.

Unlike previous models, however, we leverage the predicted weather type features z computed by the hyper-network h to generate the parameters of the depthwise convolution layers, so that pictures degraded by different weather types will be processed by different filters adaptively.

The feature vector z is fed into a 2-layer projection MLP (named HyperMLP in Fig. 2) since it is intended to generate the parameters of other modules, then reshaped to the 2D depthwise convolution kernels W (omitting the batch dimension) that are used to convolve the input X.
final_answer: Vanilla Transformers do not inherently model local pixel interactions. To introduce this local inductive bias, MWFormer inserts a depthwise convolution into each Transformer feed-forward block. Moreover, since different weather degradations require different local filtering, the network uses the weather feature vector z and a small HyperMLP to dynamically generate the depthwise convolution kernels. This lets the model adapt its local filtering to the predicted weather condition, improving restoration under varied local degradations.

question: How are upper triangular Gram matrices transformed by MLPs to produce normalized weather embeddings?
relevant_context: We utilize the first two scales of the Transformer encoders, where a Gram matrix is computed at each scale. Since Gram matrices are symmetric, only the upper triangular parts of the two matrices are vectorized to save computation.
These vectors are further fed to the two projection layers (MLPs), thereby generating two 64-dimensional embeddings.
Finally, the two embeddings are concatenated and projected onto a single feature vector , which encodes the weather-degradation information from the input image.

Each of these two vectors is then passed through its own MLP to produce a 64-dimensional embedding. Finally, the two 64-D outputs are concatenated and linearly projected into a single weather-degradation feature vector (which is then L‚ÇÇ-normalized in the contrastive learning pipeline).

question: How does the validator mechanism evaluate and filter local model updates before miner processing?
relevant_context: Subsequently, each validator v examines worker transactions œÑ_k, one at a time, in a sequential manner until all transactions are verified. Different validators should share the worker transactions they received with peers, ensuring that each validator receives all worker transactions for the current communication round. Subsequently, v discards the transaction data without a digital signature, proceeds to extract m_k^t from œÑ_k with a digital signature and evaluate its validity using the DFLoc validator mechanism. Afterward, v issues either a positive or negative vote, denoted as Œ±_k^t, based on the outcome of the validation process.

In the t-th communication round, a validator v typically evaluates the quality of the update model m_k^t by comparing its testing localization accuracy Acc(m_k^t) against that of a single-epoch trained local model, denoted as mÃÉ_k, on the worker‚Äôs test dataset D_k^test, as suggested by [26]. If noise distorts m_k^t, Acc(m_k^t) will differ, leading to a decline in accuracy compared to mÃÉ_k. Conversely, unaltered m_k^t yields minimal differences between Acc(m_k^t) and Acc(mÃÉ_k). Notably, v lacks access to m_k^t, so it cannot directly obtain the value pair (Acc(m_k^t),Acc(mÃÉ_k)).

A viable solution to address this issue involves validator v initially conducting a single-epoch of local learning by using global model m_g^t and its train dataset D_v^train to obtain a local update model mÃÉ_v, and computing the performance of mÃÉ_v and m_g^t under v‚Äôs test dataset D_v^test, denoted as Acc(mÃÉ_v) and Acc(m_g^t), respectively. Subsequently, they serve as the proxy evaluation for Acc(m_k^t) and Acc(mÃÉ_k).

In BFC, validator v evaluates the potential distortion of m_k^t by calculating the validation accuracy difference, denoted as ŒîÃÉ_k = Acc(m_g^t) ‚àí Acc(mÃÉ_v), and comparing it to a validator-threshold value œÑ. The hypothesis behind this is that the value of ŒîÃÉ_k will differ between an update sent by a legitimate worker and that by a malicious worker. If ŒîÃÉ_k exceeds œÑ, indicating that the accuracy drop exceeds v‚Äôs tolerance threshold, validator v assigns a negative vote to m_k^t; otherwise, v issues a positive vote.

In the LLR part, validator v calculates the validation loss ratio, denoted as ŒìÃÉ_k = L(mÃÉ_v)/L(m_g^t), following the computation of L(mÃÉ_v) and L(m_g^t). This ratio is then compared to a validator-threshold value œÉ to assess the potential distortion of m_k^t. Similarly, v issues a positive vote if ŒìÃÉ_k is below œÉ and a negative vote otherwise.
final_answer: Each validator first discards any unsigned worker transactions, then extracts the submitted local update m_k^t and applies the DFLoc validator mechanism to decide whether to accept or reject it. Since v cannot directly measure the worker‚Äôs true update, v trains its own single‚Äêepoch model mÃÉ_v from the current global model on its local data and evaluates both mÃÉ_v and the global model on its test set. For classification (BFC), v computes the proxy accuracy drop ŒîÃÉ_k and compares it to a threshold œÑ; for regression (LLR), v computes the proxy loss ratio ŒìÃÉ_k and compares it to a threshold œÉ. If the metric exceeds its threshold, the update is deemed malicious and receives a negative vote; otherwise it receives a positive vote. Only updates with more positive than negative votes are forwarded to miners for aggregation.
